p.s: Description of Agromyces neolithicus sp. nov.

Agromyces neolithicus (ne.o.li′thi.cus. N.L. masc. adj. neolithicus referring to the origin of the neolithic paintings in Grotta dei Cervi, the source of the soil from which the organism was isolated).
Cells form branching hyphae (width 0·3–0·5 μm) that break up into irregular diphtheroid and rod-like non-motile fragments.
Gram-positive, aerobic and microaerophilic, growing between 15 and 37 °C (optimal growth at 28 °C).
Colonies are circular, convex, smooth and beige.
Phenotypic characteristics, including antibiotic susceptibility, are reported in Table 1.
In addition, acid is also produced from starch, d-arabinose, arbutin, cellobiose, aesculin, fructose, l-fucose, galactose, glucose, glycerol, glycogen and mannose.
Predominant menaquinones are MK-13 and MK-12.
Amino acid composition of the cell wall includes diaminobutyric acid, glutamic acid, glycine and alanine.
Whole cell sugars are glucose, galactose and mannose.
Major polar lipids are diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylglycerol, two unknown phospholipids and an unknown glycolipid.
Predominant fatty acids are anteiso-C15 : 0 and anteiso-C17 : 0.
The G+C content of the type strain is 65·3 mol%.
